notes: AI could accelerate climate solutions but also increase energy consumption; climate crisis could redirect resources from AI development
AI advancement intensifies strategic competition and creates incentives for technological decoupling between blocs
AI could address labor shortages from aging populations; demographic shifts could accelerate AI adoption
These scenarios represent opposite technological trajectories and cannot occur simultaneously
AI could enable new forms of governance but also create surveillance capabilities that challenge democracy
AI productivity gains could reduce financial stress, but transition costs and inequality could trigger instability
AI development and biological catastrophes are largely independent events
Transformative AI represents major disruption inconsistent with managed stability approach
AI transformation could prevent collapse through solutions, but rapid change could also contribute to instability
Climate stress drives resource competition and migration, fragmenting international cooperation
Climate impacts drive massive migration flows and compound demographic pressures
Climate crisis could redirect resources from innovation, while tech stagnation limits climate solutions
Climate stress challenges democratic legitimacy while potentially enabling authoritarian emergency powers
Climate disasters create massive costs that stress financial systems and sovereign debt
Climate change could release pathogens from permafrost or stress ecosystems in ways that increase pandemic risk
Accelerating climate crisis with cascading effects is incompatible with managed stability
Climate crisis is a primary driver of the compound crises that could lead to systemic collapse
Migration pressures and labor shortages exacerbate international tensions and competition for workers
Fragmentation reduces international cooperation needed for innovation and creates inefficient duplication
Fragmentation often involves democratic backsliding and authoritarian consolidation in competing blocs
Fragmentation disrupts global financial integration and can trigger economic crises
Reduced international cooperation hinders pandemic preparedness and response coordination
Breakdown of global order is incompatible with managed stability and institutional resilience
Fragmentation reduces global coordination needed to address compound crises effectively
Labor shortages might drive innovation, but aging populations could reduce R&D investment
Generational changes drive political transformation, while demographic stress challenges existing systems
Aging populations create massive fiscal pressures on healthcare and social security systems
Demographic trends and biological catastrophes are largely independent phenomena
Gradual demographic changes are compatible with managed stability but create ongoing pressures
Demographic pressures contribute to fiscal and social stresses that could compound other crises
Tech stagnation might reduce surveillance capabilities but also limit tools for democratic innovation
Lower productivity growth and innovation could contribute to economic stagnation and financial stress
Limited technological progress could hinder pandemic preparedness and response capabilities
Tech stagnation is consistent with incremental change and conservative approaches to innovation
Lack of technological solutions could limit society's ability to address compound crises
Economic inequality and financial stress drive political transformation and challenge democratic legitimacy
Health emergencies can justify authoritarian measures and reshape governance models
Fundamental political transformation is inconsistent with managed stability and gradual change
Political system breakdown is both a driver and consequence of systemic collapse
Pandemics create economic disruption while financial stress limits pandemic preparedness
Severe financial system breakdown is incompatible with managed stability
Financial system breakdown is a major component and amplifier of systemic collapse
A severe global pandemic would disrupt managed stability and incremental approaches
A severe pandemic could trigger or contribute to broader systemic breakdown
These scenarios represent opposite outcomes - institutional resilience versus system breakdown
